title: Malachi Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Malachi chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Malachi Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Malachi Chapter 3.

questions.question: Who does the LORD say He will send to prepare the way before Him?
questions.correctAnswer: His messenger
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:1 states that the LORD will send His messenger to prepare the way before Him.

questions.question: What is the LORD compared to in Malachi 3:2?
options: A refiner's fire and fullers' soap
questions.correctAnswer: A refiner's fire and fullers' soap
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:2 compares the LORD to a refiner's fire and fullers' soap.

questions.question: According to Malachi 3:3, what will the LORD purify?
questions.correctAnswer: The sons of Levi
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:3 says the LORD will purify the sons of Levi as silver and gold are purified.

questions.question: What will happen to the offering of Judah and Jerusalem, according to Malachi 3:4?
options: It will be pleasant unto the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: It will be pleasant unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:4 states that the offering of Judah and Jerusalem shall be pleasant unto the LORD.

questions.question: Which groups of people does the LORD say He will be a swift witness against in Malachi 3:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Sorcerers, adulterers, false swearers, oppressors
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:5 lists these groups against whom the LORD will be a swift witness.

questions.question: True or False: Malachi 3:6 says that God changes His mind frequently.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:6 states that the LORD does not change, which is why the sons of Jacob are not consumed.

questions.question: What does God want the people to do according to Malachi 3:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Return unto Him
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:7 calls for the people to return unto the LORD so He will return unto them.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Will a man rob ______? Yet ye have robbed me.'
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:8 asks if a man will rob God, stating the people have robbed Him in tithes and offerings.

questions.question: What is the consequence mentioned in Malachi 3:9 for robbing God?
questions.correctAnswer: Being cursed with a curse
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:9 says the people are cursed because they have robbed God.

questions.question: According to Malachi 3:10, what will happen if the people bring all the tithes into the storehouse?
options: God will open the windows of heaven and pour out a blessing
questions.correctAnswer: God will open the windows of heaven and pour out a blessing
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:10 promises blessings if tithes are brought into the storehouse.

questions.question: True or False: Malachi 3:11 says the devourer will destroy the fruits of the ground.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:11 states the LORD will rebuke the devourer so it will not destroy the fruits.

questions.question: What will all nations call the people if they obey according to Malachi 3:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Blessed
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:12 says all nations will call the people blessed because they will be a delightsome land.

questions.question: What do the people say about serving God in Malachi 3:14?
options: It is vain to serve God
It is joyful to serve God
It is easy to serve God
It is profitable to serve God
questions.correctAnswer: It is vain to serve God
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:14 records the people's complaint that serving God is in vain.

questions.question: True or False: According to Malachi 3:15, the wicked are often considered happy and delivered.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:15 says that the proud and wicked are called happy and are delivered.

questions.question: Who will be written in the book of remembrance according to Malachi 3:16?
options: Those that feared the LORD and thought upon His name
questions.correctAnswer: Those that feared the LORD and thought upon His name
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:16 states a book of remembrance was written for those fearing the LORD and thinking upon His name.

medium.title: Malachi Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Malachi Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Malachi 3 teach us about trusting God's provision in times of financial uncertainty?
options: By encouraging us to bring tithes to the storehouse and promising blessings
By instructing us to save money without giving to the church
By telling us to only give offerings when we have surplus
questions.correctAnswer: By encouraging us to bring tithes to the storehouse and promising blessings
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:10 encourages bringing all tithes into the storehouse with the promise that God will open the windows of heaven and pour out blessings. This teaches us to trust God’s provision through faithful giving. Verses 10-12 reinforce God’s promise to bless and protect.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels discouraged about serving God because they see wicked people prosper. How does Malachi 3 address this concern?
options: The proud and wicked will ultimately face judgment and distinction will be made
The wicked will always prosper and the righteous will suffer
God does not notice wickedness or pride
Everyone is treated the same regardless of their actions
questions.correctAnswer: The proud and wicked will ultimately face judgment and distinction will be made
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:15-18 notes that although the wicked seem to be happy, God hears those who fear Him, writes a book of remembrance, and will make a distinction between the righteous and the wicked. This offers hope and assurance of God's justice.

questions.question: What lesson about honesty and integrity in the workplace is taught in Malachi 3?
options: Do not oppress the hireling in his wages
It is acceptable to delay paying workers
Financial disputes are unimportant to God
questions.correctAnswer: Do not oppress the hireling in his wages
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:5 specifically condemns those who oppress the hireling in his wages, teaching the importance of fairness and honesty in paying workers. This underscores God’s concern for integrity in daily work relations.

questions.question: How does Malachi 3 encourage believers to respond when they have drifted away from God's ordinances?
options: Return to God and He will return to you
Ignore the past and continue as before
Seek other gods to find new ways
Wait for God to act without personal change
questions.correctAnswer: Return to God and He will return to you
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:7 calls believers to repentance by returning to God, with the promise that He will also return to them. This teaches the virtue of humility and reconciliation with God.

questions.question: What does Malachi 3 teach about the importance of spiritual purification and personal holiness?
options: God will purify the sons of Levi like silver refined by fire
Holiness is optional for God's people
Purification is only for priests, not for all believers
God tolerates impurity among His people
questions.correctAnswer: God will purify the sons of Levi like silver refined by fire
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:3 describes God as a refiner and purifier who will purify the sons of Levi as silver and gold, teaching the importance of holiness and righteousness in service to God.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with doubt about whether God really hears their prayers. What encouragement does Malachi 3 provide?
options: Those who fear the LORD speak often one to another and God hears and writes a book of remembrance
Prayer is unnecessary since God already knows everything
Only public prayers are heard by God
questions.correctAnswer: Those who fear the LORD speak often one to another and God hears and writes a book of remembrance
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:16 shows that God listens attentively to those who fear Him and remembers their faithfulness, encouraging believers to persevere in prayer and fellowship.

questions.question: According to Malachi 3, what is the consequence of robbing God by withholding tithes and offerings?
options: The people are cursed with a curse
God will reward them despite their actions
questions.correctAnswer: The people are cursed with a curse
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:9 clearly states that robbing God in tithes and offerings brings a curse upon the whole nation, emphasizing the importance of faithful stewardship.

questions.question: How does Malachi 3 describe God's unchanging nature, and how does this encourage believers?
options: The LORD does not change, therefore the sons of Jacob are not consumed
Believers must adapt because God changes
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD does not change, therefore the sons of Jacob are not consumed
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:6 emphasizes God's immutability, which provides assurance and stability for believers, showing that God's covenant faithfulness persists.

questions.question: What does Malachi 3 say about the attitude of some towards serving God and keeping His ordinances?
options: Some say it is vain to serve God and question the profit of keeping His ordinances
Everyone eagerly serves God with joy
Serving God is seen as the greatest reward
questions.correctAnswer: Some say it is vain to serve God and question the profit of keeping His ordinances
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:14 records complaints that serving God is vain and that keeping His ordinances brings no profit, highlighting struggles with faith and motivation in obedience.

questions.question: How does Malachi 3 encourage believers to demonstrate faithfulness in family and community life?
options: By offering righteous offerings and living in holiness
By focusing only on personal gain
questions.correctAnswer: By offering righteous offerings and living in holiness
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:3-4 teaches that purified offerings and righteousness restore the relationship with God, which reflects faithful living in family and community.

questions.question: True or False: According to Malachi 3, God promises to protect the fruits of the ground and the vineyard from destruction when His people are faithful.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:11 promises that God will rebuke the devourer so the fruits of the ground and the vineyard will not be destroyed, showing His protection over faithful believers’ provision.

questions.question: True or False: Malachi 3 says that God will ignore those who fear Him and think upon His name.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:16 states that the LORD hearkened and heard those who feared Him and thought upon His name, showing God’s attentive care for His faithful people.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Malachi 3:12 says that all nations shall call you ______ because you shall be a delightsome land.
questions.correctAnswer: blessed
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:12 promises that all nations will call God’s people blessed because they will be a delightsome land, highlighting the blessings of faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Malachi 3 instruct believers to approach judgment and accountability in their daily lives?
options: God comes near to judge swiftly against sorcerers, adulterers, false swearers, and oppressors
People can escape judgment by ignoring God
Only religious leaders will be judged
questions.correctAnswer: God comes near to judge swiftly against sorcerers, adulterers, false swearers, and oppressors
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:5 describes God’s swift judgment against various sins, teaching believers to live with integrity and accountability.

questions.question: According to Malachi 3, what is the result of being refined and purified by God?
options: They may offer the LORD an offering in righteousness
They are separated from the community
questions.correctAnswer: They may offer the LORD an offering in righteousness
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:3 teaches that refinement purifies God’s people so they can offer righteous offerings, emphasizing the importance of holiness in worship and life.

hard.title: Malachi Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Malachi Chapter 3.

questions.question: What role does the messenger in Malachi 3:1 serve in relation to the Lord, and which New Testament figure is commonly identified with this messenger?
options: He prepares the way before the Lord; John the Baptist
He defeats the enemies of Israel; Paul
questions.correctAnswer: He prepares the way before the Lord; John the Baptist
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:1 speaks of a messenger who prepares the way before the Lord. This role is typologically fulfilled by John the Baptist in the New Testament, who prepares the way for Jesus Christ.

questions.question: In Malachi 3:2-3, the Lord is compared to what two refining agents, and what is the theological significance of this imagery?
options: Refiner's fire and fullers' soap; purification of the priests and people
Strong wind and heavy rain; judgment on the wicked
Hammer and anvil; forging a new covenant
Shepherd and gate; protection and guidance
questions.correctAnswer: Refiner's fire and fullers' soap; purification of the priests and people
questions.explanation: The metaphor of refiner's fire and fullers' soap in Malachi 3:2-3 symbolizes the purifying and sanctifying process God uses to cleanse the sons of Levi and prepare them for righteous offerings.

questions.question: According to Malachi 3:5, which groups will the Lord act swiftly against during His coming judgment?
options: Sorcerers, adulterers, false swearers, oppressors of hirelings, widows, fatherless, and those who deny foreigners justice
Kings, priests, prophets, merchants, and scribes
Those who neglect the Sabbath and dietary laws
questions.correctAnswer: Sorcerers, adulterers, false swearers, oppressors of hirelings, widows, fatherless, and those who deny foreigners justice
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:5 lists specific groups against whom God will act as a swift witness, emphasizing social justice and covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: What does Malachi 3:6 emphasize about God's nature, and how does this relate to the covenant with Jacob's descendants?
options: God does not change; thus, the sons of Jacob are not consumed
God is merciful and forgetful; He forgives all sins
God is distant and unknowable; His plans are secret
God is angry and punishing; He will destroy the nation
questions.correctAnswer: God does not change; thus, the sons of Jacob are not consumed
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:6 underscores God's immutability, explaining why despite Israel's failings, the descendants of Jacob have not been destroyed.

questions.question: What accusation does God make against Israel in Malachi 3:8, and what specific practice does this relate to in the covenant context?
options: Robbing God by withholding tithes and offerings
Breaking the Sabbath and dietary laws
Ignoring the prophets and their messages
questions.correctAnswer: Robbing God by withholding tithes and offerings
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:8 explicitly accuses Israel of robbing God by not bringing their tithes and offerings, a covenant obligation meant to support the temple and priests.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Malachi 3:10: 'Bring ye all the _____ into the storehouse, that there may be meat in mine house.'
questions.correctAnswer: tithes
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:10 commands bringing all the tithes into the storehouse to ensure provision for the temple and its ministry.

questions.question: What promise does God make in Malachi 3:10 if the people bring the tithes faithfully?
options: He will open the windows of heaven and pour out a blessing
He will grant them long life and prosperity
He will give them victory over their enemies
He will establish a new king from David's line
questions.correctAnswer: He will open the windows of heaven and pour out a blessing
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:10 promises abundant blessings from God as a reward for faithful tithing, using the imagery of windows of heaven opened.

questions.question: In Malachi 3:11, what is the 'devourer' that God promises to rebuke, and what does it symbolize in the ancient Near Eastern agricultural context?
options: Pests and locusts that destroy crops; symbolizing divine protection over harvest
Foreign armies invading the land; symbolizing political oppression
False prophets leading people astray; symbolizing spiritual decay
Drought and famine; symbolizing natural judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Pests and locusts that destroy crops; symbolizing divine protection over harvest
questions.explanation: The 'devourer' in Malachi 3:11 refers to agricultural pests common in the ancient Near East, with God's promise indicating protection and blessing over the land's productivity.

questions.question: According to Malachi 3:12, how will the nations perceive those who obey God's commands, and what is the broader theological implication of this?
options: They shall be called blessed and be a delightsome land; a testimony to God's favor
They will be feared and avoided; a sign of divine judgment
They will be ignored and marginalized; reflecting Israel's exile
They will be envied and attacked; symbolizing conflict
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be called blessed and be a delightsome land; a testimony to God's favor
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:12 indicates that obedience brings national blessing and esteem among nations, emphasizing God's covenantal blessings.

questions.question: True or False: In Malachi 3:14-15, the people express that serving God is profitable and that the wicked are punished swiftly.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:14-15 reveals the people's complaint that serving God seems vain and unprofitable, and that the wicked appear to prosper instead.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Malachi 3:16-17 where the faithful are described as God's jewels, and what does this imply about their value?
options: Metaphor; implies preciousness and divine ownership
Simile; implies comparison to common stones
Allegory; represents a hidden spiritual truth
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor; implies preciousness and divine ownership
questions.explanation: The faithful being called 'jewels' in Malachi 3:17 is a metaphor expressing their great value and God's special care for them.

questions.question: How does Malachi 3:7 function as a call to repentance, and what covenantal principle does it reinforce?
options: Return to God so He will return to you; the principle of reciprocal covenant faithfulness
Sacrifice more animals to atone for sins; the principle of ritual purification
Build a new temple; the principle of divine presence in the sanctuary
Observe the Sabbath strictly; the principle of holiness
questions.correctAnswer: Return to God so He will return to you; the principle of reciprocal covenant faithfulness
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:7 is a direct appeal for Israel to repent and return to God's ways, highlighting the mutual obligations of the covenant.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'book of remembrance' mentioned in Malachi 3:16 in the context of ancient Near Eastern beliefs and biblical theology?
options: It symbolizes God's record-keeping of the faithful for future blessing and vindication
It is a physical scroll kept in the temple archives
It refers to human genealogical records for tribal identity
It symbolizes the Law written on stone tablets
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's record-keeping of the faithful for future blessing and vindication
questions.explanation: The 'book of remembrance' in Malachi 3:16 is a metaphor for God's awareness and memorial of those who fear Him, assuring their reward.

questions.question: In Malachi 3:18, what ultimate discernment will take place, and how does this relate to the theme of divine justice throughout Scripture?
options: Distinguishing between the righteous and the wicked, those who serve God and those who do not; affirming final judgment
Separating the Levites from the rest of Israel; affirming priestly purity
Choosing a new king for Israel; affirming royal authority
Identifying foreign nations for exile; affirming national punishment
questions.correctAnswer: Distinguishing between the righteous and the wicked, those who serve God and those who do not; affirming final judgment
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:18 speaks of a future time when God will clearly differentiate between the righteous and wicked, a key eschatological theme in biblical justice.

questions.question: How does the concept of 'refiner and purifier' in Malachi 3:3 connect to the purification rites of the ancient Near East and its typological fulfillment in the New Testament?
options: It parallels ritual purification and foreshadows Christ's sanctifying work through the Holy Spirit
It refers only to physical washing rites with no spiritual implication
It contrasts with pagan purification by emphasizing legalistic adherence
It symbolizes the destruction of the temple by foreign powers
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels ritual purification and foreshadows Christ's sanctifying work through the Holy Spirit
questions.explanation: The refiner and purifier imagery in Malachi 3:3 reflects ancient purification rituals and is typologically seen as fulfilled in Christ's purifying work.

theological.title: Malachi Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Malachi Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who is the messenger that will prepare the way before the Lord according to Malachi 3?
questions.correctAnswer: A prophetic forerunner of Christ
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:1 speaks of a messenger sent to prepare the way before the Lord. This is understood as a prophetic foretelling of John the Baptist (cf. Matthew 11:10; Mark 1:2-3) who prepared the way for Jesus, the messenger of the covenant. This aligns with biblical typology where a forerunner announces God's coming.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Malachi 3 to describe the Lord's coming and judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Refiner's fire and fullers' soap
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:2 uses the imagery of a refiner's fire and fullers' soap to describe God's purifying judgment. This metaphor emphasizes God's holiness and the process of sanctification, consistent with biblical themes of purification (cf. Zechariah 13:9; 1 Peter 1:7; Isaiah 1:25).

questions.question: According to Malachi 3, who will be purified like gold and silver?
questions.correctAnswer: The sons of Levi
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:3 states that the Lord will purify the sons of Levi like gold and silver so they may offer righteous offerings. This highlights the priestly role of Levi and God's call to holiness (cf. Exodus 19:6; Hebrews 7:26-28).

questions.question: What will happen to the offerings of Judah and Jerusalem after purification, as stated in Malachi 3?
options: They will be pleasant unto the LORD as in the days of old
They will be increased but not accepted
They will be burned with fire
questions.correctAnswer: They will be pleasant unto the LORD as in the days of old
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:4 teaches that after purification, the offerings of Judah and Jerusalem will be pleasing to God as in former times. This reflects restoration of covenant fellowship (cf. Psalm 51:19; Isaiah 56:7; Hebrews 13:15).

questions.question: Which sins does God specifically promise to judge in Malachi 3:5?
options: Sorcery, adultery, false swearing, oppression of hirelings, widows, orphans, and strangers
questions.correctAnswer: Sorcery, adultery, false swearing, oppression of hirelings, widows, orphans, and strangers
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:5 lists specific sins God will judge, emphasizing social justice and covenant faithfulness. This reflects God's concern for moral purity and care for the vulnerable (cf. Exodus 22:21-24; Isaiah 1:17; James 5:4).

questions.question: What unchanging attribute of God is emphasized in Malachi 3:6?
questions.correctAnswer: God's immutability
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:6 declares 'I am the LORD, I change not,' highlighting God's immutability. This attribute assures covenant faithfulness and is foundational for trust in God (cf. Hebrews 13:8; James 1:17; Psalm 102:27).

questions.question: What does God call the people to do in response to their departure from His ordinances in Malachi 3?
options: Return unto me, and I will return unto you
questions.correctAnswer: Return unto me, and I will return unto you
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:7 invites the people to repentance, promising God's reciprocal faithfulness. This call to return is a key biblical theme of repentance and restoration (cf. Joel 2:12-13; 2 Chronicles 7:14; Luke 15:18-20).

questions.question: According to Malachi 3, in what way have the people robbed God?
questions.correctAnswer: In tithes and offerings
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:8-9 accuses the people of robbing God through withholding tithes and offerings. This addresses the covenant responsibility to support the temple and priests, linking obedience with blessing (cf. Leviticus 27:30; 2 Corinthians 9:7; Proverbs 3:9-10).

questions.question: What promise does God give to those who bring all the tithes into the storehouse in Malachi 3?
options: He will open the windows of heaven and pour out a blessing
He will grant them wealth and power
He will give them long life
He will make them rulers over nations
questions.correctAnswer: He will open the windows of heaven and pour out a blessing
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:10 promises abundant blessings if the people bring tithes faithfully. This illustrates God's covenantal generosity (cf. Deuteronomy 28:12; Luke 6:38; Philippians 4:19).

questions.question: In Malachi 3, what is the 'devourer' that God says He will rebuke?
questions.correctAnswer: A destructive force harming crops
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:11 refers to the 'devourer' as a force damaging the fruits of the ground, likely locusts or pests. God's protection of their produce symbolizes His care and blessing (cf. Exodus 23:28; Joel 2:25; James 5:4).

questions.question: What will all nations do to Israel as described in Malachi 3:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Call them blessed
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:12 states that all nations will call Israel blessed, indicating a restored and favored status among the peoples. This echoes promises of blessing in Genesis 12:3 and Isaiah 60:3.

questions.question: What complaint do the people make against God in Malachi 3:14?
options: It is vain to serve God
questions.correctAnswer: It is vain to serve God
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:14 records the people's complaint that serving God brings no profit. This reflects a common human struggle with divine justice (cf. Ecclesiastes 1:3; Job 21:7; Habakkuk 1:3).

questions.question: Who does Malachi 3:15 say are considered happy by the people despite their wickedness?
options: The proud and those who work wickedness
questions.correctAnswer: The proud and those who work wickedness
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:15 notes the people's perception that the proud and wicked prosper, challenging the notion of divine justice (cf. Psalm 73:3-12; Ecclesiastes 8:14; Jeremiah 12:1).

questions.question: What is written in the book of remembrance according to Malachi 3?
options: The names of those who fear the LORD and think upon His name
questions.correctAnswer: The names of those who fear the LORD and think upon His name
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:16 describes a book of remembrance for those who fear God and honor His name, signifying divine recognition and reward (cf. Psalm 69:28; Daniel 12:1; Revelation 20:12).

questions.question: How does God describe those who fear Him in Malachi 3:17?
options: As His jewels, spared like a son
questions.correctAnswer: As His jewels, spared like a son
questions.explanation: Malachi 3:17 portrays the faithful as precious jewels belonging to God, whom He spares lovingly like a father his son. This imagery affirms divine affection and protection (cf. Psalm 139:17-18; 1 Peter 2:9; Isaiah 43:4).
